Measure: 1.1 Please share the definition(s):
OBS_VALUE: The Australian Government uses the following definition in its Evaluation Toolkit - 'Evaluation is the systematic and objective assessment of the design, implementation or results of a government program or activity for the purposes of continuous improvement, accountability and decision-making. It provides a structured and disciplined analysis of the value of policies, programs and activities at all stages of the policy cycle.' Individual line ministries in the Australian Government use different variations on this definition to suit the individual circumstances of the ministry.

OBS_VALUE: The mandate of these units is determined by Policy on Results, the Financial Administration Act and the discretion of departments and agencies through the Departmental Evaluation Plan (DEP). The DEP is a five-year, rolling plan developed by the departmental evaluation unit that assesses evaluation needs in consultation with departments (initiative leads and Assistant Deputy Ministers) as well as TBS and approved by the Deputy Head and the departments Performance Measurement and Evaluation Committee (PMEC).

Measure: 5.1 How is the mandate of these evaluation units in line ministries established?
OBS_VALUE: The mandate of these units is determined by Policy on Results, the Financial Administration Act and the discretion of departments and agencies through the Departmental Evaluation Plan (DEP). The DEP is a five-year, rolling plan developed by the departmental evaluation unit that assesses evaluation needs in consultation with departments (initiative leads and Assistant Deputy Ministers) as well as TBS and approved by the Deputy Head and the departments Performance Measurement and Evaluation Committee (PMEC).

Measure: 1.1 Please share the definition(s):
OBS_VALUE: Evaluation is the systematic and neutral collection and analysis of evidence to judge merit, worth or value.   Evaluations: • inform decision making, improvements, innovation and accountability; • focus on programs, policies and priorities, but, depending on user needs, can also examine other units, themes and issues, including alternatives to existing interventions; • examine questions related to relevance, effectiveness and efficiency; and • employ social science research methods

Measure: 1.1 Please share the definition(s):
OBS_VALUE: Il existe plusieurs définitions car le terme “évaluation” recouvre plusieurs conceptions différentes au sein des administrations publiques et en dehors. Voici quelques-unes des définitions :   DREES (actes du séminaire sur les méthodes d’évaluation des politiques publiques, 2011) : « L’évaluation de l’action publique (politique, programme, dispositif) a pour objet d’en apprécier la valeur au regard de certains critères, comme la pertinence, l’efficacité, l’efficience…, notamment dans le but d’apporter des connaissances pour aider à la décision et éclairer le débat public ». (Annie Fouquet, SFE).  C’est sur la base de cette définition de la Société française d’évaluation (SFE) que les évaluations de politique publique dans le cadre de la MAP (Modernisation de l’action publique, 2012-2017) ont été conduites (memo sur l’évaluation des politiques publiques de la MAP, 2015) : “Les questions évaluatives visent à interroger l’ensemble de la chaîne de valeur d’une action publique à partir des critères évaluatifs standards (efficacité, efficience, cohérence, utilité, pertinence) et des orientations structurantes de la modernisation (simplification, innovation, numérique, ouverture des données, soutenabilité...) ».  Décret du 18 novembre 1998 (no 98-1048) : « L’évaluation d’une politique publique, au sens du présent décret, a pour objet d’apprécier, dans un cadre interministériel, l’efficacité de cette politique en comparant ses résultats aux objectifs assignés et aux moyens mis en œuvre ».  Décret du 22 janvier 1990 (no 90-82) : « L’évaluation d’une politique publique au sens du présent décret a pour objet de rechercher si les moyens juridiques, administratifs ou financiers mis en œuvre permettent de produire les effets attendus de cette politique et d’atteindre les objectifs qui lui sont assignés ».

Measure: Policies that result from international commitment (e.g. European funds) need to be evaluated. Please provide the weblink here:-comment
OBS_VALUE: EU Regulations 1303/2013 (https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32013R1303&qid=1656002870577, for the 2014-2020 programming cycle) and 2021/1060 (https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32021R1060 ,for 2021-2027), provide for the mandatory ex-ante evaluation of programmes with regard to their effectiveness, efficiency, relevance and consistency, as well as an ex post evaluation for each policy priority of the programmes to analyse their impact. Therefore, all Managing Authorities of EU-cofunded programmes have produced evaluations over time: NUVAP, as part of SNV activities, collects information about these evaluations, which are available at the webpage: https://www.valutazionecoesione.it/attivita-di-sistema/osservatorio.html As well, for the Common Agricultural Policy, EU Regulations 1306/2013 and 1305/2013 (https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/AUTO/?uri=celex:32013R1306, for the 2014-2020 programming cycle) and 2021/2115 (https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX%3A32021R2115, for the 2023-2027 programming cycle) make mandatory the ex-ante evaluation, the strategic environmental, assessment, the evaluation during the programming period and ex-post evaluation according to the specific requirements that are set by common monitoring and evaluation framework (CMEF, https://agriculture.ec.europa.eu/common-agricultural-policy/cap-overview/cmef_en). Impact evaluations are conducted for state aid schemes that fall under the EU General Block Exemption Rule and that exceed 150 million EUR per year or 750 million EUR over the entire period. These evaluation reports are available on the EU commission website https://microeconomicevaluation.jrc.ec.europa.eu/evaluation-report?f%5B0%5D=member_state_taxonomy_term_name%3AIT.

OBS_VALUE: Government Policy Evaluations Act Article 6(1)?The Head of an Administrative Organ (when the organ is the Fair Trade Commission, National Public Safety Commission, Personal Information Protection Commission, Environmental Dispute Coordination Commission or Nuclear Regulation Authority, it is the respective commission or authority; the same applies hereinafter) must draw up a basic plan for Policy Evaluation (hereinafter referred to as 'Basic Plan') based on the Basic Guidelines for a term longer than three years but not longer than five years for policies under the jurisdiction of the Administrative Organ.  (2)The basic plan prescribes the following matters: (i) …  (vi)matters related to the conduct of Ex-post Evaluation, including policies to be subjected to evaluation during the planning period;   (3)The Head of an Administrative Organ prescribes as the policies pursuant to the provisions of the preceding paragraph, item (vi), those that serve as principal organizational objectives to be realized in response to social and economic circumstances, under its organizational missions.

Measure: Other, please specify
OBS_VALUE: art.29.3 Law 27/2022, of December 20, 2002:  i) The promotion of the evaluation culture.  m) Representing the General State Administration before international organizations and institutions in matters of public policy evaluation.

Measure: Other, please explain
OBS_VALUE: As mentioned in question 2 related to the objectives of Law 27/2022, of December 20, it aims to: - Encourage the development of evidence-based public policies. - Support the efficiency and effectiveness of public spending. - Improve accountability and transparency in decision making.  The Chapter of the Law regulates the incorporation of evaluation results into public decision making. The purpose of this Chapter is to ensure that those who must make decisions on public action take into account the results gathered in the evaluation reports when continuing, abandoning or redesigning a public policy that has already been evaluated. Likewise, the Final Evaluation Report will be published within one month of its receipt on the thematic portal for the evaluation of public policies, without prejudice to its publication also on the Transparency Portal of the General State Administration, guaranteeing general access and derived from the application of the obligations regarding active publicity provided for in Law 19/2013, of December 9, on transparency, access to information and good governance. Finally, it should be noted that in the annual report to the Cortes Generales regulated in art. 30 of Law 27/2022 is intended to account for the general state of the institutionalization of the evaluation of public policies, the monitoring of the results of the evaluations and compliance with the law.
